action_space.name: Therapeutic Alliance Establishment and Maintenance
action_space.description: Establish and continually strengthen a collaborative, empathic, and trusting relationship between therapist and patient.

goal.objective: Build a strong, collaborative partnership that promotes engagement and openness in therapy.

success_levels.ideal: Patient actively engages, feels understood, safe, and trusts both the therapist and the process.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient participates and expresses basic trust, with occasional reservations that are collaboratively managed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is disengaged, guarded, or mistrustful, impeding therapeutic progress.

goal.reward_hint: Patient openly provides feedback, participates actively, and expresses a sense of safety/trust.

states: Beginning contact or first session with a new patient
Patient expresses hesitance, mistrust, or reluctance to collaborate
Therapist recognizes strain or lack of strength in the therapeutic alliance
End of session (to elicit feedback about relationship or process)
Patient gives negative feedback about the therapist or session
Patient expresses discomfort with session structure or therapist style

micro_actions.name: Demonstrate Warmth, Empathy, and Respect
micro_actions.description: Express genuine care, understanding, and regard for the patient through verbal affirmations, body language, and attentive listening.

micro_actions.name: Acknowledge and Validate Patient Emotions
micro_actions.description: Reflect back and validate the patient's feelings (e.g., 'I can see this is difficult for you'), without disputing or minimizing their distress.
states: Patient provides negative feedback or criticism
Therapist senses negative affect after interruption or structure

micro_actions.name: Invite and Reinforce Patient Feedback
micro_actions.description: At session end or after key interventions, ask for feedback on therapist style, session flow, or alliance and respond supportively to both positive and negative input.
states: Therapist senses alliance is strong or weak
Patient displays hesitance to share negative feelings

micro_actions.name: Adjust Therapist Style in Response to Patient Preferences
micro_actions.description: Request input on therapist’s approach (e.g., level of warmth or directness) and modify style to match patient comfort while maintaining therapeutic boundaries.
states: Therapist detects alliance rupture after style mismatch
Patient shows discomfort with therapist approach

micro_actions.name: Empathically Address Session Structure Resistance
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge the patient’s discomfort with agenda or structure, collaboratively negotiate alternatives, and validate the patient’s experience.
states: Patient expresses negative reaction to structure
Patient is new to CBT or unfamiliar with session structure

micro_actions.name: Seek Supervision or Support When Therapist Cannot Endorse Alliance
micro_actions.description: Recognize personal difficulties in feeling empathy or positive regard, discuss with a supervisor, and address automatic thoughts interfering with alliance.
states: Therapist recognizes an inability to endorse positive messages

action_space.name: Collaborative Agenda-Setting and Session Structuring
action_space.description: Establish the priorities and structure for each session collaboratively with the patient.

goal.objective: Organize session time efficiently to address patient needs and maintain focus on therapeutic goals.

success_levels.ideal: Agenda is jointly set and followed, covering prioritized patient issues; patient feels heard and motivated.
success_levels.acceptable: Partial agenda alignment; some unplanned topics discussed but core items addressed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Session is unstructured, unfocused, or dominated by tangents; patient's main concerns are missed.

goal.reward_hint: Session maintains agreed structure, covers scheduled topics, and adjusts collaboratively as needed.

states: Session beginning or planning (any phase of therapy)
Patient provides new concerns or wants to deviate from agenda
Multiple or unfocused issues arise during session
Patient resists structure or feels uncomfortable with formal agenda
Time management is needed (e.g., many agenda items or limited time)

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Set and Prioritize Agenda Items
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to list topics they wish to discuss, summarize proposed items, and jointly decide which to address first, deferring others if necessary.
states: Time is limited; too many items listed

micro_actions.name: Acknowledge and Incorporate Patient Concerns
micro_actions.description: Validate new issues presented by the patient and explicitly include them in the agenda or plan a future discussion.
states: Patient brings up additional items during agenda setting

micro_actions.name: Redirect Unfocused or Tangential Discussion
micro_actions.description: Gently interrupt lengthy, unfocused, or off-topic talk and guide the patient back to agreed agenda items, explaining the rationale for structure.
states: Patient elaborates at length outside of agenda

micro_actions.name: Provide Rationale and Negotiate Structure
micro_actions.description: Explain the benefits of session structure to the patient and negotiate compromises, such as patient-led time, when resistance occurs.
states: Patient expresses a preference for an unstructured session

micro_actions.name: Teach and Monitor Agenda-Setting Skills
micro_actions.description: Actively model succinct labeling of problems, assign homework to generate agenda items, and provide corrective feedback as needed for engagement.
states: Patient does not contribute or rambles

action_space.name: Psychological Assessment and Cognitive Conceptualization
action_space.description: Gather data, conceptualize the patient's difficulties within the cognitive model, and share/revise formulations collaboratively.

goal.objective: Develop a shared understanding of patient problems in cognitive terms to inform treatment planning.

success_levels.ideal: Complete, accurate, and jointly endorsed cognitive formulation guides effective interventions.
success_levels.acceptable: Tentative or partially accurate conceptualization, refined over time.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Conceptualization is absent, superficial, or diverges from patient experience, leading to ineffective interventions.

goal.reward_hint: Patient resonates with and provides input on cognitive formulation; therapist adapts based on new information.

states: New patient or new data arises
Conceptualizing specific difficulties or updating formulation
Explaining cognitive model or treatment approach
Introducing cognitive-behavioral therapy to patients used to other modalities

micro_actions.name: Systematically Gather Assessment Data
micro_actions.description: Ask targeted questions about symptoms, history, functioning, coping strategies, strengths, risks, and relevant contextual factors at the start of therapy.

micro_actions.name: Formulate and Revise Cognitive Conceptualization
micro_actions.description: Integrate patient data into a working formulation, clearly articulating links between thoughts, beliefs, behaviors, and emotions; revise as new information is presented.
states: After assessment or when new symptoms/problems reported

micro_actions.name: Share and Check Conceptualization with Patient
micro_actions.description: Summarize the cognitive formulation in the patient’s language, invite feedback on its accuracy or relevance, and collaboratively modify if needed.

micro_actions.name: Use Patient’s Experience to Illustrate Cognitive Model
micro_actions.description: Relate recent patient problems or experiences to the cognitive model to facilitate understanding and relevance.

action_space.name: Problem and Goal Identification
action_space.description: Clarify specific problems and collaboratively set concrete, attainable behavioral goals for therapy.

goal.objective: Transform patient difficulties into actionable, self-controlled objectives that guide intervention.

success_levels.ideal: All key problems are clearly identified and reframed as specific, achievable goals aligned with patient priorities.
success_levels.acceptable: Some problems/goals remain vague or broad but are gradually refined.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Goals are not set, remain too vague, or do not address patient needs.

goal.reward_hint: Goals are clearly written, understood, and accepted by both therapist and patient.

states: Patient describes current problems or distress
Patient struggles to define or specify goals

micro_actions.name: Empathic Problem Clarification
micro_actions.description: Use open questions and reflective listening to clarify the nature, origin, and impact of each problem described by the patient.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Reframe Problems as Attainable Goals
micro_actions.description: Help patient rephrase vague or broad issues into specific, behavioral, and self-controlled goals, explaining rationale as needed.
states: Goals are too broad or focused on others

micro_actions.name: Record and Review Goals in Writing
micro_actions.description: Write down agreed goals, review them at future sessions, and adjust collaboratively as progress occurs or priorities shift.

micro_actions.name: Screen for Suicidality When Appropriate
micro_actions.description: Assess for risk if language about giving up, overwhelming distress, or symptoms suggest self-harm; prioritize safety.

action_space.name: Teaching and Socializing to the Cognitive Model
action_space.description: Educate the patient about the cognitive-behavioral model and its principles using personalized examples and aids.

goal.objective: Ensure the patient understands how thoughts, emotions, and behaviors interact and the rationale for CBT techniques.

success_levels.ideal: Patient grasps the model, applies it to personal issues, and engages in CBT practices independently.
success_levels.acceptable: Basic conceptual understanding is present, needing occasional reinforcement or aids.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient remains confused or skeptical, impeding use of CBT methods.

goal.reward_hint: Patient demonstrates understanding by explaining the cognitive model in their own words.

states: Patient is unfamiliar with CBT or cognitive conceptualization
Patient struggles to differentiate thoughts, feelings, or behaviors
Difficulty understanding/modeling the cognitive connection between events, thoughts, and emotions

micro_actions.name: Personalize Illustration of Cognitive Model
micro_actions.description: Use patient’s recent experience to demonstrate relationship between situation, thoughts, emotions, and behaviors, highlighting the cognitive triad.

micro_actions.name: Use Visual Aids or Concrete Examples
micro_actions.description: Employ diagrams, charts, or physical objects to visibly demonstrate the cognitive model; limit abstract explanation for those who struggle.
states: Patient has difficulty understanding cognitive model

micro_actions.name: Prompt Patient to Paraphrase Understanding
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to describe in their own words how thoughts, emotions, and behaviors interact; clarify misunderstandings.

micro_actions.name: Reassure and Downplay Model Importance if Needed
micro_actions.description: If patient struggles persistently, reassure that mastering the model can take time and plan to revisit in future sessions.
states: Ongoing confusion or frustration about model

action_space.name: Identification of Automatic Thoughts and Associated Reactions
action_space.description: Help patient recognize automatic thoughts, images, and associated emotional, behavioral, or physiological responses.

goal.objective: Increase patient awareness of automatic cognitive processes impacting mood and behavior.

success_levels.ideal: Patient independently identifies and records automatic thoughts and reactions during/after relevant situations.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient identifies thoughts with prompting or in-session guidance.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is unable to recognize or differentiate automatic thoughts from emotions or interpretations.

goal.reward_hint: Patient names automatic thoughts and associated reactions with increasing clarity.

states: Patient expresses distress or dysfunctional emotion/behavior
Strong emotion or affective shift in session
Homework or in-session identification of thoughts/images
Difficulty with labeling thoughts or distinguishing them from feelings

micro_actions.name: Ask Targeted Questions to Elicit Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Use prompts like 'What was going through your mind just then?' to help identify automatic cognitions at moments of distress.

micro_actions.name: Employ Techniques for Difficult Thought Identification
micro_actions.description: Use bodily feeling prompts, encourage narration or visualization, or role play; suggest opposite thoughts or uncover meaning if patient struggles.

micro_actions.name: Clarify and Differentiate Interpretations from Actual Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Guide patient to provide plain words or images that went through their mind, distinguishing these from emotions or interpretations.
states: Patient gives interpretation or emotion instead of thought

micro_actions.name: Train Patient in Daily-Life Thought Identification
micro_actions.description: Teach patient to notice mood changes, ask themselves what just went through their mind, and record these thoughts for review.

micro_actions.name: Identify and Label Associated Emotional, Behavioral, and Physiological Reactions
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to link each automatic thought to their emotional state, behaviors, and physical sensations.
states: In-session or homework review of thoughts
Patient struggles to link thoughts and feelings

action_space.name: Evaluation and Restructuring of Automatic Thoughts
action_space.description: Collaboratively examine, reality-test, and develop adaptive responses to distressing automatic thoughts using Socratic questioning and related techniques.

goal.objective: Reduce distress and dysfunctional behavior by challenging maladaptive thinking and fostering healthier alternatives.

success_levels.ideal: Patient consistently evaluates and generates adaptive responses to automatic thoughts, reducing symptoms.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient can evaluate and shift some thoughts with support; distress decreases partially.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient remains stuck in dysfunctional cognitions; distress and dysfunction persist.

goal.reward_hint: Patient's belief in dysfunctional thoughts and associated distress decrease after evaluation.

states: Automatic thoughts identified and judged distressing/dysfunctional
Patient engages in cognitive distortion or has entrenched negative beliefs
Session focus on evaluating beliefs and reality-testing
Patient expresses doubts about ability to shift thinking

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Socratic Questioning
micro_actions.description: Pose open-ended questions about evidence for and against the thought, alternative explanations, and possible outcomes, without direct confrontation.
states: Patient distressed or stuck in thinking

micro_actions.name: Label and Teach Cognitive Distortion Recognition
micro_actions.description: Identify, name, and explain cognitive distortions in patient’s thoughts, providing lists or examples for practice.

micro_actions.name: Adapt Questioning When Standard Approaches Fail
micro_actions.description: Vary the format or focus of Socratic questions when patient remains stuck, including open-ended or belief-based queries.
states: Patient is resistant to standard questioning

micro_actions.name: Introduce and Practice Thought Record Tools
micro_actions.description: Teach use of written or audio Thought Records, model completion in-session, and assign as homework for independent skill development.
states: Homework is assigned for thought evaluation

micro_actions.name: Evaluate Belief and Emotional Distress Pre- and Post-Intervention
micro_actions.description: Ask patient to rate belief in the thought and emotional intensity before and after restructuring; review progress and outcomes.

micro_actions.name: Model Adaptive Self-Talk and Coping Cards
micro_actions.description: Compose coping cards or summaries with the patient to record adaptive responses and encourage rehearsal between sessions.
states: Patient continues to struggle with adaptation

action_space.name: Intermediate and Core Belief Identification and Restructuring
action_space.description: Uncover, assess, and collaboratively modify deeper intermediate and core beliefs underlying recurring negative patterns.

goal.objective: Promote enduring change by transforming rigid, maladaptive beliefs at an emotional and intellectual level.

success_levels.ideal: Central beliefs are identified and successfully replaced by adaptive alternatives, leading to measurable change.
success_levels.acceptable: Some progress in recognition/modification; new beliefs partially adopted.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Core beliefs remain negative and unmodified; patient relapses or lacks progress.

goal.reward_hint: Patient increasingly endorses adaptive beliefs and uses them across contexts.

states: Recurring themes or rigid negative beliefs revealed
Downward arrow or other belief identification techniques in use
Patient expresses interest in belief change or shows emotional attachment to beliefs
Worksheets, role-play, or behavioral experiments assigned for belief restructuring

micro_actions.name: Downward Arrow Technique for Belief Identification
micro_actions.description: Ask repetitive, probing questions (e.g., 'What would it mean if that thought were true?') to uncover intermediate and core beliefs.
states: Recurring negative thoughts or central themes

micro_actions.name: Present Belief Hypotheses for Patient Confirmation
micro_actions.description: Verbally hypothesize a core or intermediate belief and request patient’s feedback, confirmation, or modification.

micro_actions.name: Assess Strength and Breadth of Belief Endorsement
micro_actions.description: Ask patient to rate how strongly and broadly a belief is held, using 0–100% scales and examples from multiple life domains.

micro_actions.name: Educate on the Nature of Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Explain that beliefs are learned, modifiable, and maintained by attention to certain data; normalize belief change.
states: Patient is ready for or open to belief change

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Formulation and Testing of Alternative Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Suggest plausible, adaptive new beliefs and use Socratic questioning, behavioral experiments, role-play, and comparison with external references to foster endorsement.
states: Patient expresses interest or shows emotional attachment

micro_actions.name: Monitor Emotional and Intellectual Endorsement
micro_actions.description: Regularly have patient rate both intellectual and emotional endorsement of old and new beliefs, and reinforce progress.

micro_actions.name: Assign Homework to Reinforce New Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Instruct patient to gather and record evidence that supports new beliefs, review and rerate daily as booster or maintenance.

action_space.name: Behavioral Activation and Experimentation
action_space.description: Encourage patient engagement in pleasurable, mastery, and exposure-based activities to challenge avoidance, test predictions, and promote change.

goal.objective: Increase patient activity, confront avoidance, and gather evidence to modify dysfunctional predictions about action or mood.

success_levels.ideal: Patient regularly engages in planned activities, gathers data, overcomes avoidance, and mood improves.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient participates in some activities with guidance, testing predictions and experiencing partial mood improvement.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient resists activity scheduling; avoidance and negative beliefs persist unabated.

goal.reward_hint: Patient completes experiments/activities and reports new insights or changes in mood.

states: Patient is depressed, avoidant, or predicts negative outcomes from activity
Behavioral activation is required (e.g., inactivity, low mastery/pleasure)
Need for exposure to feared situations or beliefs
Experimentation to test automatic thoughts or core beliefs

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Activity Identification and Scheduling
micro_actions.description: Work with patient to choose and schedule pleasurable and mastery-enhancing activities, considering interests and current capacity.

micro_actions.name: Design Behavioral and Exposure Experiments
micro_actions.description: Jointly create in-session or homework experiments to test beliefs or predictions (e.g., feared situations, social experiments, exposure hierarchy).
states: Patient expresses avoidance or predicts negative outcomes

micro_actions.name: Label and Challenge Automatic Thoughts Interfering with Activity
micro_actions.description: Help patient identify and reality-test negative predictions that hinder activity engagement; reframe homework as an experiment.
states: Patient is reluctant or unable to act

micro_actions.name: Monitor and Reinforce Effort and Progress
micro_actions.description: Encourage patient to give themselves explicit credit for small steps; compare progress with their worst point, not ideal functioning.

micro_actions.name: Use Activity Charts and Ratings
micro_actions.description: Assign activity or pleasure/mastery charts to monitor predicted vs. actual outcome, review and use data to plan next steps.

micro_actions.name: Address and Normalize Skepticism or Doubt
micro_actions.description: Validate doubts about behavioral activation, propose trial experiments, gather actual data, and review discrepancies with patient.

action_space.name: Skill Building and Coping Strategy Training
action_space.description: Teach, model, and practice adaptive life skills, coping strategies, and problem-solving methods in-session and through homework.

goal.objective: Equip patient with practical skills and strategies to address real-life challenges and maintain progress.

success_levels.ideal: Patient learns, practices, and independently uses new skills and strategies, reporting improved functioning.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient applies some skills with therapeutic support; progress is gradual.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient lacks necessary skills or does not use them due to belief barriers; problems persist.

goal.reward_hint: Patient demonstrates use of new coping/problem-solving skills in their daily life.

states: Patient lacks problem-solving or life/social skills
Therapist assigns skills training or modeling
Patient is blocked from using skills due to dysfunctional beliefs

micro_actions.name: Direct Instruction in Needed Skills
micro_actions.description: Teach specific skills (e.g., communication, decision-making, relaxation) using demonstration, explanation, and written guides as appropriate.

micro_actions.name: Role Play and Rehearsal of Skills
micro_actions.description: Practice targeted skills in session using real-life scenarios; encourage patient to experiment outside of sessions.
states: Social or behavioral skill development needs

micro_actions.name: Assign Coping Strategy Practice as Homework
micro_actions.description: Provide tailored homework exercises to reinforce in-session skill development, adapting tasks to be manageable, clear, and relevant.

micro_actions.name: Address Belief Barriers to Skill Use
micro_actions.description: Identify and collaboratively challenge dysfunctional beliefs interfering with skill deployment (e.g., fears about social engagement), possibly using role play.

action_space.name: Imagery Work: Identification and Restructuring
action_space.description: Help patients identify distressing images, practice intervention strategies to transform imagery, and use imagery techniques for coping or change.

goal.objective: Reduce emotional distress and modify dysfunctional beliefs by addressing and changing mental imagery.

success_levels.ideal: Patient identifies, modifies, and rehearses realistic and adaptive images, resulting in emotional relief.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient learns to notice and describe images, tries some interventions with partial reduction in distress.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient remains stuck in distressing images, refuses intervention, or experiences no benefit.

goal.reward_hint: Patient reports reduced distress or new insights from imagery transformation.

states: Patient reports or is suspected to have distressing mental images
Patient confused about or avoids discussing images
Guided imagery or coping rehearsal needed in anticipation of challenges

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Clarify Mental Images Associated with Distress
micro_actions.description: Ask patient about mental pictures, daydreams, fantasies, or memories accompanying distressing emotions or thoughts, using synonyms for clarity.
states: Patient reports distress without mentioning images

micro_actions.name: Normalize and Encourage Disclosure of Distressing Images
micro_actions.description: Address embarrassment or fear by normalizing intrusive/distressing images and gently encourage patient disclosure.
states: Patient reluctant to share distressing images

micro_actions.name: Teach and Practice Imagery Intervention Strategies
micro_actions.description: Guide patient to modify or complete distressing images, rehearse coping actions in mental imagery, and practice realistic or magical imagery for relief.

micro_actions.name: Use Socratic Questioning to Reality-Test Images
micro_actions.description: Help patient evaluate evidence for and against the reality or likelihood of the image, comparing to real-life experiences.
states: Image is exaggerated or not realistic

micro_actions.name: Rehearse Coping Strategies via Positive Mental Imagery
micro_actions.description: Induce imagery of challenge scenarios, help patient visualize coping successfully, and practice both in-session and as homework.

micro_actions.name: Substitute Pleasant or Neutral Images for Distressing Ones
micro_actions.description: Direct patient to imagine positive soothing scenes and practice switching from distressing to comforting imagery.

action_space.name: Collaborative Homework Assignment and Review
action_space.description: Assign, tailor, and review homework collaboratively, with a focus on experimentation, skill practice, and reinforcing therapy gains.

goal.objective: Promote independent skill use, reinforce session learning, and foster self-efficacy through ongoing practice.

success_levels.ideal: Patient sets, completes, and reviews homework regularly, integrating skills into everyday life.
success_levels.acceptable: Homework is completed irregularly with therapist support; obstacles are addressed as needed.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient does not engage in homework; skill generalization is absent.

goal.reward_hint: Homework is completed and reviewed collaboratively; patient reports increased confidence/self-management.

states: Session ends or key skill/intervention is learned
Homework is being assigned or reviewed
Patient expresses resistance, difficulty, or uncertainty about homework
Patient initiates self-therapy after treatment ends

micro_actions.name: Provide Clear Rationale for Homework
micro_actions.description: Explain the purpose of each assignment, its relevance to therapy goals, and how completion will help the patient.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Design and Tailor Homework
micro_actions.description: Work with the patient to match homework to their abilities, needs, and session topics; adjust complexity as needed.
states: Patient has difficulty or expresses doubts

micro_actions.name: Anticipate and Problem-Solve Obstacles
micro_actions.description: Discuss potential barriers to homework completion, rehearse solutions, and use covert rehearsal or role play if confidence is low.

micro_actions.name: Review and Reinforce Homework Efforts
micro_actions.description: Discuss completed assignments, praise effort, and use setbacks as opportunities to collaboratively modify or plan next steps.
states: Reviewing homework at start or end of session

micro_actions.name: Set Up Systems for Homework Adherence
micro_actions.description: Help patient devise reminders, cueing strategies, or pair homework with routine activities to increase completion rates.
states: Patient is disorganized or lacks accountability

action_space.name: Problem-Solving and Decision-Making Facilitation
action_space.description: Collaborate with patient to address distressing life problems through structured problem-solving and decision-making techniques.

goal.objective: Help patient find effective, actionable solutions and increase confidence in managing challenges.

success_levels.ideal: Problems are addressed using structured strategies, patient feels competent and empowered in decisions.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient participates and generates some solutions with therapist support.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Problems remain unsolved or patient is paralyzed by indecision/avoidance.

goal.reward_hint: Patient describes trying new solutions and feels increased problem-solving efficacy.

states: Patient presents new, distressing real-life problems
Patient is procrastinating, avoiding, or lacks decision-making skills

micro_actions.name: Encourage Agenda Inclusion and Collaborative Brainstorming
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to add real-life problems to the agenda and brainstorm potential solutions together.

micro_actions.name: Provide Direct Instruction and Recommend Skills Training
micro_actions.description: Teach or suggest problem-solving, communication, or decision-making techniques as needed, referencing self-help materials when applicable.

micro_actions.name: Challenge Dysfunctional Beliefs Blocking Solutions
micro_actions.description: Identify limiting beliefs, collaboratively evaluate and restructure them before moving forward with solution generation.

micro_actions.name: Use Structured Evaluation for Major Decisions
micro_actions.description: Guide patient in listing pros/cons of each option, weighting importance, and facilitating a reasoned choice.
states: Patient is unsure how to proceed

micro_actions.name: Assign Solution-Oriented Homework Experiments
micro_actions.description: Encourage patient to conduct behavioral experiments or trial solutions, and review outcomes next session.

action_space.name: Session Summarization, Progress Review, and Feedback Collection
action_space.description: Summarize key session points, review therapy progress, and actively elicit and address patient feedback.

goal.objective: Enhance patient understanding, reinforce learning, and continuously improve therapy via collaborative review.

success_levels.ideal: Patient and therapist summarize, review gains, clarify misunderstandings, and adapt therapy based on feedback.
success_levels.acceptable: Progress is reviewed and feedback is elicited with occasional oversights or incomplete summaries.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Session ends without review or feedback; misunderstandings or missed opportunities persist.

goal.reward_hint: Patient actively participates in summarization and provides detailed feedback.

states: Review of homework or therapy gains
Patient or therapist observes lack of progress or dissatisfaction
Prior to therapy termination or booster sessions

micro_actions.name: Provide and Elicit Session Summary
micro_actions.description: Summarize main points of the session using the patient's language where possible and ask the patient to summarize their takeaways if appropriate.

micro_actions.name: Check Accuracy of Patient's Summary
micro_actions.description: Review patient’s summary for completeness or correctness, offer alternative phrasing if needed, and confirm agreement before recording.

micro_actions.name: Review and Modify Homework Assignments as Needed
micro_actions.description: Discuss completed homework, reinforce progress, collaboratively adjust assignments and plan next steps.

micro_actions.name: Actively Solicit and Respond to Feedback
micro_actions.description: Invite feedback on session content, therapist style, or progress; explore any negative reactions or misunderstandings empathetically.
states: Patient gives critical or hesitant feedback

action_space.name: Therapy Termination and Relapse Prevention Planning
action_space.description: Prepare for ending therapy, teach self-therapy skills, and collaboratively plan for relapse prevention and maintenance.

goal.objective: Empower patient to independently manage future setbacks using CBT skills and structured relapse prevention plans.

success_levels.ideal: Patient organizes therapy notes, practices self-therapy, uses coping plans, and effectively manages setbacks.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient is aware of relapse prevention strategies, seeks support when needed, and applies learned skills.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is anxious, unprepared or highly dependent on therapist after termination; skills are unused and relapse risk is high.

goal.reward_hint: Patient initiates self-therapy, describes coping plans, and demonstrates confidence in independent management.

states: Patient fears relapse or expresses anxiety about managing independently
Booster sessions or post-termination difficulties arise
Patient expresses missing the therapist or need for external support

micro_actions.name: Review Therapy Gains and Organize Notes
micro_actions.description: Summarize key therapy skills, encourage patient to compile, organize, and review notes or worksheets for future reference.

micro_actions.name: Identify and Rehearse Self-Therapy Steps
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively discuss steps for independent problem-solving, thought evaluation, and coping; assign rehearsal tasks.

micro_actions.name: Develop and Review Written Relapse Prevention Plan
micro_actions.description: Create a brief, written plan outlining steps to be taken during setbacks, including reminders of cognitive strategies and when to seek external support.

micro_actions.name: Reframe Setbacks and Encourage Self-Efficacy
micro_actions.description: Normalize setbacks, review coping strategies, encourage trial of independent skill use before reaching out for help.
states: Setback reported during final sessions or booster

micro_actions.name: Address Emotional Reactions to Termination
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge feelings about the end of therapy, validate progress, and support building wider networks or resources.

conversation_states.Description: The current strength of the collaborative relationship, mutual trust, and sense of partnership between therapist and patient. Essential for patient engagement, openness, and effective intervention.

The intensity of the patient’s psychological distress, negative affect, or discomfort experienced during the session or related to current problems. Influences session structure, intervention choice, and pacing.
Degree to which patient is actively involved in agenda-setting, feedback, homework, and therapeutic tasks. Important for collaboration, motivation, and self-efficacy.

How precise and well-developed the therapist’s understanding of the patient’s beliefs, cognitive processes, and history is, including core/intermediate beliefs and automatic thoughts. Guides intervention selection and session focus.
Clarity and specificity of the primary problems or symptoms discussed and agreed upon for therapy focus. Facilitates agenda-setting and targeted interventions.
Degree to which identified automatic thoughts are distressing, dysfunctional, and likely to recur, requiring intervention and ongoing monitoring.
How strongly the patient holds central core or intermediate beliefs and the level of emotional/intellectual buy-in. Affects readiness for cognitive change and choice of strategy.
Extent to which the session follows structured CBT components (mood check, agenda, homework review, summary, feedback) vs. becomes unstructured or tangential.
Degree to which the patient completes, understands, and benefits from homework assignments; includes reporting obstacles to completion and need for adaptation.
Patient’s ability to distinguish between thoughts, feelings, behaviors, and interpretations; necessary for effective cognitive restructuring and use of CBT tools.
Patient’s optimism, willingness to try new strategies, and belief in capacity for improvement; relates to engagement, progress, and relapse risk.
Degree to which mood and affect (as observed or reported) shift during session; includes presence of affective shifts or affect congruence with content.
Level of patient proficiency in using CBT skills such as identifying automatic thoughts, evaluating beliefs, using thought records, and self-therapy strategies.
Patient’s ability to collaboratively generate solutions, implement problem-solving steps, and use skills independently inside and outside session.
Level of avoidance of tasks, situations, emotions, or therapy activities; identifies need for behavioral experiments or exposure interventions.
The degree of match between interventions/techniques used and the patient’s needs, stage, and feedback during the session; requires ongoing adaptation.
Degree to which session goals are met, meaningful change or new learning occurs, and obstacles are addressed.
Current risk factors for suicide, harm, or crisis, including expressions of hopelessness, suicidal ideation, or acute distress. Impacts session focus and priority for intervention.
Therapist’s own automatic thoughts, beliefs, and emotional reactions about self, patient, or therapy; self-awareness is crucial for maintaining effectiveness.
How collaboratively agenda, goals, interventions, and feedback are generated and acted on by both therapist and patient.
Frequency, type, and distress level of mental images reported or elicited in session; important for addressing imagery-based cognitions and fears.
Degree to which patient is engaging in pleasurable or mastery activities to counter inactivity and dysphoria; key in behavioral activation interventions.
How well patient is applying learned CBT skills between sessions and after therapy ends; relates to relapse prevention and independence.

nodes.description: Root node representing the individual receiving CBT.
The patient’s psychiatric, psychological, or behavioral diagnosis(es).
Specific difficulties, symptoms, or situations leading the patient to seek therapy.
Quality of trust, collaboration, empathy, and rapport between therapist and patient.
Behavioral, cognitive, or emotional objectives set collaboratively, including short- and long-term aims.
The patient’s knowledge of the CBT/cognitive model and their ability to apply it to their own experiences.
Patient’s participation in agendas, feedback, collaboration, and structured elements of sessions.
Recurring, spontaneous thoughts in specific situations influencing emotion and behavior.
The patient's ability to identify, articulate, and monitor automatic thoughts during and outside sessions.
Comprises core and intermediate beliefs (assumptions, rules, attitudes) about self, others, and world.
The most deeply held, overgeneralized beliefs about self (themes: helplessness, unlovability, worthlessness).
Conditional assumptions, rules, and attitudes (e.g., 'If X, then Y').
Patterns of biased, illogical, or inaccurate thinking (e.g., catastrophizing, dichotomous thinking).
Tendency to focus on negative experiences, self-criticism, or selectively filter out positive data.
The patient’s awareness of, ability to label, and strategies for managing emotions.
Patterns and intensity of emotional states, including tracking of distress, mood shifts, and negative affect.
Behavioral responses such as avoidance, withdrawal, procrastination, or safety behaviors.
Positive behavioral responses, problem-solving skills, activity scheduling, and use of new coping skills.
Role of mental images (intrusive, distressing, or adaptive) in the patient’s emotional distress and belief system.
Attendance, completion, and barriers to assigned between-session tasks and experiments.
Subjective and objective evidence of improvement or setbacks; attribution style for progress.
Skills, coping plans, and attitudes towards potential setbacks, including readiness for self-therapy and maintenance.
Current phase (early, middle, final/termination) and main therapeutic focus for the stage.
Overall willingness, ambivalence, or obstacles to participating in therapy and making changes.
Influences beyond therapy (family, stressors, biological/medical, medications) affecting progress.

cautions.negative_action: Challenge or dispute the patient's emotions directly
cautions.description: Do not challenge, invalidate, or argue with the patient's emotions.
cautions.risk: May damage the therapeutic alliance, increase distress, or make the patient feel misunderstood.

cautions.negative_action: Impose CBT structure rigidly or in a controlling manner
cautions.description: Do not enforce structure or session agenda in a demanding, uncollaborative way.
cautions.risk: Risks damaging rapport, increasing resistance, and reducing patient engagement in therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Focus on the therapeutic alliance when unnecessary
cautions.description: Do not emphasize the alliance excessively when it is sound; instead, prioritize active problem-solving.
cautions.risk: Wastes valuable session time and may frustrate the patient by not addressing their pressing issues.

cautions.negative_action: Challenge core beliefs too early in entrenched cases
cautions.description: Do not attempt direct modification of deeply held core beliefs without sufficient preparation.
cautions.risk: Can lead to increased resistance, distress, or disengagement from therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Move forward with unfounded conceptualizations
cautions.description: Do not make interpretations or hypotheses about the patient's beliefs or problems without adequate supporting data.
cautions.risk: May result in misunderstanding, loss of trust, and ineffective treatment planning.

cautions.negative_action: Use stigmatizing, judgmental, or jargon-heavy language when discussing diagnosis
cautions.description: Avoid language that could be interpreted as stigmatizing or overly technical.
cautions.risk: Can foster shame, misunderstanding, or avoidance, harming engagement and progress.

cautions.negative_action: Neglect to check for or address patient feedback or discomfort
cautions.description: Do not ignore signs (verbal or nonverbal) that the patient may be struggling with the process or content of therapy.
cautions.risk: Can result in unresolved alliance ruptures, unaddressed dissatisfaction, and therapy dropout.

cautions.negative_action: Assign impractically difficult or poorly defined homework
cautions.description: Do not give homework that is too challenging, vague, or misaligned with the patient's abilities or current state.
cautions.risk: Increases likelihood of non-adherence, discouragement, or reinforced feelings of incompetence.

cautions.negative_action: Persist with standard techniques despite patient distress or strong negative reaction
cautions.description: Do not continue with cognitive or experiential interventions if patient is overwhelmed or experiencing excessive distress.
cautions.risk: May worsen the patient's emotional state and reduce willingness to participate in future therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Skip risk assessment when signs of suicidality or hopelessness are present
cautions.description: Do not neglect to prioritize safety planning when risk factors are identified.
cautions.risk: Potential for not addressing immediate safety needs, leading to severe patient harm.

cautions.negative_action: Over-focus on unproductive discourse or off-topic conversation
cautions.description: Do not allow the session to devolve into lengthy, unstructured, off-topic discussion.
cautions.risk: Limits progress, reduces time for therapeutic work, and can reinforce avoidance patterns.

cautions.negative_action: Neglect review and reinforcement of homework and skills
cautions.description: Do not fail to review completed homework or skills learned in therapy.
cautions.risk: Weakens transfer of learning, reduces patient accountability, and may result in loss of therapeutic gains.

cautions.negative_action: Directly persuade or debate negative automatic thoughts
cautions.description: Do not attempt to convince the patient that their negative automatic thoughts are incorrect through argument.
cautions.risk: Undermines collaborative empiricism, increases defensiveness, and diminishes cognitive change.

cautions.negative_action: Overemphasize or excessively probe past events without clear rationale
cautions.description: Do not focus sessions on childhood or historical factors in a way that detracts from present-focused interventions, except when directly relevant to current beliefs.
cautions.risk: May reinforce rumination and distract from actionable problem-solving and skills acquisition.

cautions.negative_action: Fail to adapt session structure and techniques for patient diversity
cautions.description: Do not rigidly apply techniques without considering the patient's background, needs, abilities, and preferences.
cautions.risk: Reduces effectiveness, can alienate patients, and risks cultural or developmental insensitivity.

cautions.negative_action: Neglect collaborative agenda-setting and prioritization
cautions.description: Do not unilaterally set the session agenda or ignore the patient's input.
cautions.risk: Reduces engagement, fosters resistance, and undermines patient autonomy.

cautions.negative_action: Base problem conceptualization on labels or negative judgment of the patient
cautions.description: Avoid attributing issues to character flaws; instead focus on behaviors and cognitions.
cautions.risk: Increases stigma, damages the therapeutic alliance, and can reinforce negative self-schema.

cautions.negative_action: Fail to check patient understanding before moving on
cautions.description: Do not proceed without verifying that the patient understands key concepts, tasks, or rationale.
cautions.risk: May cause confusion, reduce skill acquisition, and undermine progress.

cautions.negative_action: Continue to focus on a problem or thought that is no longer relevant or distressing
cautions.description: Do not persist in evaluating or discussing an issue once the patient has resolved or is not distressed by it.
cautions.risk: Wastes valuable time and may cause frustration or disengagement.

cautions.negative_action: Neglect to prepare for and support therapy termination and relapse prevention
cautions.description: Do not end therapy abruptly or without preparing the patient for possible setbacks, ongoing self-therapy, and maintenance.
cautions.risk: Increases likelihood of relapse, dependence on the therapist, or lack of follow-through on gains.

user_profile.Description: Patient's readiness, motivation, and consistency in participating in CBT and related interventions.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = completely disengaged; 1 = fully engaged and motivated in therapy sessions, goal-setting, and homework)

user_profile.Description: Ability to recognize symptoms, understand their impact, and participate in self-reflective dialogue.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = lacks insight/denies symptoms/refuses reflection; 1 = consistently demonstrates accurate self-understanding and reflection)

user_profile.Description: Typical ability to manage and tolerate negative emotions, distress, and impulses.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = frequent emotional dysregulation/impulsivity; 1 = effective, adaptive emotional regulation in and outside sessions)

user_profile.Description: Stability of cognitive processes such as attention, memory, executive function, and reality testing.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = severely impaired cognition/attention/disorientation; 1 = fully intact cognition across settings and times)

user_profile.Description: Patient’s typical approach to relationships, communication, and collaboration with the therapist (e.g., openness, trust, social withdrawal).
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = highly conflictual/withdrawn/no trust; 1 = warm, open, collaborative, and trusting)

user_profile.Description: Stability, salience, and openness of patient's cultural, ethnic, and identity attributes as they impact therapy.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = completely avoidant/stigmatized; 1 = fully open and integrated into therapy, views identity as strength)

user_profile.Description: Habitual strategies for managing stressors, symptoms, and adversity (e.g., adaptive, avoidant, reliant on substances).
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = consistently maladaptive/catastrophizing/avoidant/substance reliant; 1 = consistently adaptive, flexible, and constructive)

user_profile.Description: Patient’s awareness and engagement regarding co-occurring psychiatric or medical issues affecting their presenting problem.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = denies/ignores comorbidities; 1 = fully aware and willing to address co-occurring disorders in therapy)

user_profile.Description: Existence, stability, and quality of support system; use or avoidance of family/community resources.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = completely isolated/antagonistic family or environment; 1 = strong, consistent, and constructive support network)

user_profile.Description: Patient's typical attitudes toward psychiatric illness, treatment, and associated stigma; willingness to seek help.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = high stigma/strong reluctance and avoidance of care; 1 = no stigma, fully open to help-seeking and therapeutic alliance)

user_profile.Description: Level of distress and impairment across occupational, academic, and social domains due to psychiatric symptoms.
user_profile.Numerical values: (0 = complete dysfunction across domains; 1 = fully functional, no impairment noted)
